topic.title: Managing Connections Using the PHP SDK with Couchbase Server
topic.shortdesc: This section describes how to connect the PHP SDK to a Couchbase cluster and bucket. It contains best practices as well as information on the connection string, SSL and other advanced connection options.

body.p: To manage Couchbase Server connections, you need to configure the client, connect to a bucket, and configure SSL.

section.title: Configuring the Client
section.p: To configure the client, instantiate a new Cluster object:

In addition to the connection string passed to the Cluster object, you can include a user name and password. The user name and password are required to perform management operations against your cluster. If you do not use the cluster management aspects of the SDK, the user name and password parameters are optional. Keep in mind that these credentials are the same ones you use to log in to the Couchbase administrator console, not those specified for the bucket itself.

section.title: Authentication
section.p: In addition to regular authentication, when you provide password to openBucket() and manager() methods. It is possible to define all credentials in single place, and associate with container, which could be used for all future connections.

Since version 2.3.0 PHP SDK provides interface \Couchbase\Authenticator which is implemented by all credentials containers, and the library can pull authentication parameters from it when it is necessary. For release 2.3.0, there is only one implementation of this interface: \Couchbase\ClassicAuthenticator, but upcoming releases will also have RBAC support. The using of authenticator is simple:

It is still possible to specify password to openBucket() or cluster's manager(), and in this case password-argument will take precedence. But such behaviour is discouraged, and future implementations of \Couchbase\Authenticator interface might raise error once the SDK detects mixing of authentication sources.

section.title: Disconnecting from a Bucket
section.p: To close the connection to a bucket, call its disconnect() method. This method queues the disconnection of all open connections and causes any pending operations to fail.

section.title: Scalability and concurrency
section.p: Creating a new Bucket object is relatively expensive, and keeping many idle Bucket objects will negatively impact server performance (if done at a large scale).
PHP SDK by default uses persistent connections to reuse underlying IO objects if the connection strings are the same.
